intro: Habracanthus smithii, commonly known as the Smith's habracanthus, is a rare flowering plant native to specific regions of South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its delicate, palmate leaves and showy, five-petaled flowers that bloom in spring. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and requires a humid climate to flourish. Due to habitat loss, it is considered endangered and is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
